Reading through these comments, I see a remarkable socio-cultural clash theme emerging between the US and... the Dutch! The US — a land where anyone from anywhere can pick themselves up, put down roots, start anew, thrive, succeed—in other words, a land of immigrants and opportunity. And one where the taxpayers pay for everything.

The Dutch — a place that values privileged educations, subsidizes foreign workers, and pays

River Queen attempts to pack a complicated, sweeping, historical narrative into just under two hours. There are some breathtaking battle scenes and the Wanganui scenery is beautiful, but the crowding and the overuse of jump-cuts make it feel more like a three-minute television clip than a full-length motion picture. Both sex and violence are overused to the point where these components are laughable and distracting (especially when shown in graphic slow-mo).

The Bone Snatcher is about a group miners who go on a search for a missing crew of miners in the Namib Desert. When the find them, the crew are found in an area with spikes with feeding tubes going all over the place and several skeletons and bodies half eaten. So what are they now involved with???? This movie really reminded me of a movie starring Dolph Lundgren called The 7th How to Make a Million Fast and Got It Off the Bone .

I saw it tonight and fell asleep in the movie.

That is something that I have not done since - I have never fallen asleep at a real movie in a theater..

However, I was too tired to watch John Carter and fell asleep with approximately 20 minutes left to the movie. Since I missed the ending, now I can go see the movie again and guess what kind of ending it has? Just kidding......

Michael Dudikoff stars as Joe Armstrong a martial artist who fights ninjas who are stealing weapons from the U.S Army, in this entertaining yet admittedly brainless comedic action film. This film is the first of three starring the martial artist. The film was shot in the Philippines, and it shows with the difference in culture, colors, and thick accent of the supporting actors.
